bestBHT.bht: The rebukes that stung Herod’s conscience might have contributed to his decision to imprison John, and it's possible that Herodias was also affected by these rebukes. Luke often anticipates what follows in his writing. The omission of the conjunction that before shut up is called asyndeton. The verb shut up is rarely used in the New Testament, with only two instances, including this one. Matthew 14:3 provides more information about John's imprisonment, which took place in the castle of Machaerus. This mention of the imprisonment before Jesus' baptism ensures a smooth narrative progression.

Henry Alford: The same rebukes which stung Herod’s conscience and aided the desire to imprison John, might work on that conscience."
Vv. 19, 20 are in anticipation of what follows; which is in St. Luke’s manner; see ch. i. 80.
Archibald T. Robertson: The absence of the conjunction οτ (that) before the next verb κατεκλεισεν (shut up) is asyndeton.
It is an old and common verb, though here and Acts 26:10 only in the N.T.
See Matthew 14:3 for further statement about the prison.
John Gill: This sin to all other sins, and which was of a more flagitious nature; and attended with more aggravating circumstances, especially in the issue of it.
That he shut up John in prison.
In the castle of Machaerus, by the instigation of Herodias.
John Wesley: This circumstance, though it happened after, is here mentioned before our Lord's baptism.
That his history (that of John being concluded) may then follow without any interruption.

bhtAttempts.bht: The rebukes that stung Herod's conscience and led to John's imprisonment may have also affected Herodias, explaining Herod's decision to shut John up. This anticipation of what follows is characteristic of Luke's writing style. The absence of the conjunction that before the verb shut up is asyndeton, a deliberate omission for rhetorical effect. The verb shut up is rarely used in the New Testament and is only found here and in Acts 26:10. Matthew 14:3 provides additional details about John's imprisonment in the castle of Machaerus. By mentioning this before Jesus' baptism, Luke ensures a smooth flow in the narrative, allowing the reader to focus on the story without interruption.

Luke mentions this before Jesus' baptism to ensure a smooth narrative flow.

The rebukes that stung Herod’s conscience might have contributed to his decision to imprison John, and it's possible that Herodias was also affected by these rebukes. Luke often anticipates what follows in his writing. The omission of the conjunction that before shut up is called asyndeton. The verb shut up is rarely used in the New Testament, with only two instances, including this one. Matthew 14:3 provides more information about John's imprisonment, which took place in the castle of Machaerus. This mention of the imprisonment before Jesus' baptism ensures a smooth narrative progression.

The rebukes that stung Herod's conscience likely played a role in his decision to imprison John, suggesting that they may have also affected Herodias. This anticipation of what follows aligns with Luke's writing style. The asyndeton in the absence of the conjunction that before shut up creates a deliberate rhetorical effect. The rare usage of the verb shut up in the New Testament, found only here and in Acts 26:10, underscores its significance. Further details about John's imprisonment are provided in Matthew 14:3, which occurred in the castle of Machaerus. This chronological order allows for a seamless flow in the narrative.
